channel.title: New England renaissance
channel.description:
A dramatic re-creation of the New England Renaissance produced at Boston University.,A dramatic re-creation of the New England Renaissance produced at Boston University. In this part of the series, the Transcendentalists are viewed from the perspective of 1954, when this program was recorded.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Little strangeness between us
item.description: This program focuses on the story of Nathaniel Hawthorne. Topics include his friends and his literary contributions; Elizabeth Peabody's Bookstore; and minor Transcendentalists.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Brook Farm revisited
item.description: Brook Farm as it is today. Tour conducted by Reverend Harold Arnold, former pastor of the church where Theodore Parker preached.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: High thoughts-simple living
item.description: The conditions under which the Renaissance took place; background material on the Transcendentalists.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Within myself an immense force
item.description: The activities and personality of Margaret Fuller; background information in regard to the Dial and Conversations of the Transcendentalists.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Be ashamed to die
item.description: The activities of Amos Bronson Alcott and Horace Mann in the education field. Features re-creation of Alcott's Temple School in Boston based on authentic "conversations."
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Revolt against materialism
item.description: Explanation of Transcendental philosophy and its roots. Selections from works of Parker, Thoreau and Emerson.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Build, therefore, your own world
item.description: The story of the slavery question; religious and educational conflicts in the 1830s and 1840s.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Concord revisited
item.description: A documentary tour of Concord, Mass., as it was when the program was recorded in 1954, stressing the famous places known because of the Transcendental activity.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Like a little heaven
item.description: The story of the Brook Farm experiment in West Roxbury and the Fruitlands experiment in the town of Harvard, Massachusetts.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Family traditions
item.description: Interviews with direct descendants of Emerson and Amos Bronson Alcott on family memories and traditions.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Transcendentalists and us
item.description: A discussion of transcendental influence on modern thought featuring Dr. Perry Miller of Harvard University.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: Trust thyself
item.description: This program focuses on Ralph Waldo Emerson's early life, educational life, associations with friends, and literary activites.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Transcendentalists (New England)

item.title: To be awake is to be alive!
item.description: This program focuses on Henry David Thoreau. It features select quotations from Walden and his other writing.
item.dc:creator: Sloan, George, W., Jr.
item.dc:subject: Writing
